chunk_text: IV. Annexes

summary.summary: The Minister of Health, Minister Duclos, is thanked for agreeing to serve Canadians during the pandemic. The letter acknowledges the unprecedented challenge Canadians have faced, highlighting their adaptability, mutual support, and commitment to values such as compassion, courage, and determination throughout the pandemic.

chunk_text:
Minister of Health mandate letter

December 16, 2021

Dear Minister Duclos:

Thank you for agreeing to serve Canadians as Minister of Health.

From the beginning of this pandemic, Canadians have faced a once-in-a-century
challenge. And through it all, from coast to coast to coast, people have met
the moment. When it mattered most, Canadians adapted, helped one another, and
stayed true to our values of compassion, courage and determination. That is
what has defined our path through this pandemic so far

summary.summary: Canadians democratically chose to entrust their government to continue fighting against COVID-19, support the middle class recovery, and take bold actions to build a healthier and more resilient future. The government is committed to fulfilling these expectations.

chunk_text:
And that is what will
pave our way forward.

During a difficult time, Canadians made a democratic choice. They entrusted us
to finish the fight against COVID-19 and support the recovery of a strong
middle class. At the same time, they also gave us clear direction: to take
bold, concrete action to build a healthier, more resilient future. That is
what Canadians have asked us to do and it is exactly what our Government is
ready to deliver
policies_and_priorities_keywords: support the recovery of a strong middle class
build a healthier, more resilient future

summary.summary: We will strive for a brighter future through ongoing collaboration, active engagement, and reliance on science and evidence-based decision-making.

chunk_text:
We will work to build that brighter future through continued
collaboration, engagement, and the use of science and evidence-based decision-
making

summary.summary: The government commits to constructive collaboration with Parliamentarians and various governmental and Indigenous partners, aiming to rebuild a more resilient, inclusive, and stronger nation. Emphasizing the clarity of scientific evidence and public opinion, the commitment to accelerating and intensifying climate action is highlighted.

chunk_text:
With an unwavering focus on delivering results, we will work
constructively with Parliamentarians and maintain our strong partnerships with
provincial, territorial and municipal governments and Indigenous partners.
This decade has had an incredibly difficult start, but this is the moment to
rebuild a more resilient, inclusive and stronger country for everyone.

The science is clear. Canadians have been clear. We must not only continue
taking real climate action, we must also move faster and go further
policies_and_priorities_keywords: rebuild a more resilient, inclusive and stronger country

summary.summary: Climate change poses an existential threat to Canadians, and addressing it will necessitate a sustained, collaborative effort from all individuals.

chunk_text:
As
Canadians are increasingly experiencing across the country, climate change is
an existential threat. Building a cleaner, greener future will require a
sustained and collaborative effort from all of us

summary: The Minister is tasked with identifying opportunities within their portfolio to contribute to the government's efforts in reducing emissions, creating clean jobs, and addressing climate challenges faced by communities.

This year, Canadians were deeply affected by the discovery of unmarked graves and burial sites near former residential schools, highlighting the urgency to accelerate reconciliation efforts with First Nations, Inuit, and Métis Peoples.

chunk_text:
As Minister, I expect you
to seek opportunities within your portfolio to support our whole-of-government
effort to reduce emissions, create clean jobs and address the climate-related
challenges communities are already facing.

This year, Canadians were horrified by the discovery of unmarked graves and
burial sites near former residential schools. These discoveries underscore
that we must move faster on the path of reconciliation with First Nations,
Inuit and Métis Peoples

summary.summary: Reconciliation requires truth, and the government will continue to invest in uncovering that truth.

chunk_text:
We know that reconciliation cannot come without truth
and our Government will continue to invest in that truth

summary.summary: Each Minister is directed to implement the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples and to collaborate with Indigenous Peoples to advance their rights. The focus is on addressing systemic inequities and disparities present in societal and institutional structures.

chunk_text:
As Ministers, each
of us has a duty to further this work, both collectively and as individuals.
Consequently, I am directing every Minister to implement the United Nations
Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples and to work in partnership
with Indigenous Peoples to advance their rights.

We must continue to address the profound systemic inequities and disparities
that remain present in the core fabric of our society, including our core
institutions
policies_and_priorities_keywords: United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples
work in partnership with Indigenous Peoples
address the profound systemic inequities and disparities
organizational_structure_keywords: United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples
key_partners_keywords: United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples

summary.summary: It is crucial for Canadians across all regions to feel represented in the government's priorities and work. As Minister, you are expected to collaborate with various communities and actively incorporate the diverse perspectives of Canadians into your work.

chunk_text:
To this effect, it is essential that Canadians in every region
of the country see themselves reflected in our Government’s priorities and our
work. As Minister, I expect you to include and collaborate with various
communities, and actively seek out and incorporate in your work, the diverse
views of Canadians

summary.summary: This text highlights the commitment to inclusivity and diversity in public policy development, specifically mentioning women, Indigenous Peoples, Black and racialized Canadians, newcomers, faith-based communities, persons with disabilities, LGBTQ2 Canadians, and ensuring bilingual representation. It emphasizes the use of intersectional frameworks like Gender-based Analysis Plus (GBA Plus) and quality of life indicators in decision-making. Additionally, it notes the ongoing reliance of Canadians on journalists for accurate and timely news.

chunk_text:
This includes women, Indigenous Peoples, Black and
racialized Canadians, newcomers, faith-based communities, persons with
disabilities, LGBTQ2 Canadians, and, in both official languages.

Across our work, we remain committed to ensuring that public policies are
informed and developed through an intersectional lens, including applying
frameworks such as Gender-based Analysis Plus (GBA Plus) and the quality of
life indicators in decision-making.

Canadians continue to rely on journalists and journalism for accurate and
timely news

summary.summary: The text underscores the importance of maintaining professional and respectful relationships with journalists to ensure Canadians are well-informed and safe. It highlights the adaptability of Canadians and their governments during the pandemic and emphasizes the need for governments to learn from these experiences to develop more agile and effective methods of serving the public.

chunk_text:
I expect you to maintain professional and respectful
relationships with journalists to ensure that Canadians are well informed and
have the information they need to keep themselves and their families safe.

Throughout the course of the pandemic, Canadians and their governments have
adapted to new realities. Governments must draw on lessons learned from the
pandemic to further adapt and develop more agile and effective ways to serve
Canadians

summary.summary: The speaker is directing ministers to evaluate and update government practices to meet current and future challenges. They are also emphasizing the need for parliamentary success through cross-party collaboration in both the House of Commons and the Senate, and the importance of maintaining constructive relationships with opposition critics and coordinating legislation with the Government Leader in the House of Commons.

chunk_text:
To this end, I expect all Ministers to evaluate ways we can update
our practices to ensure our Government continues to meet the challenges of
today and tomorrow.

The success of this Parliament will require Parliamentarians, both in the
House of Commons and the Senate, to work together across all parties to get
big things done for Canadians. I expect you to maintain constructive
relationships with your Opposition Critics and coordinate any legislation with
the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
organizational_structure_keywords: Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
key_partners_keywords: Leader of the Government in the House of Commons

summary.summary: The Minister is accountable to Parliament both individually and collectively for leadership, responsibility performance, and support of the Ministry and cabinet decisions. The document 'Open and Accountable Government' outlines the principles, conduct standards, and the Minister's expected responsibilities. The platform sets an ambitious agenda.

chunk_text:
As Minister, you are
accountable to Parliament both individually, for your style of leadership and
the performance of your responsibilities, and collectively, in support of our
Ministry and decisions taken by cabinet. Open and Accountable Government sets
out these core principles and the standards of conduct expected of you and
your office. I expect you to familiarize yourself with this document, which
outlines my expectations for each member of the Ministry.

Our platform lays out an ambitious agenda

summary.summary: The central focus remains on ending the pandemic, while also building a strong middle class and ensuring a fair chance for everyone's success. As the Minister of Health, the immediate priority is to combat COVID-19 in collaboration with provinces and territories. Post-pandemic, the focus will shift to strengthening the universal public health care system, increasing investments in primary, virtual, and mental health services to ensure accessible care for all Canadians.

chunk_text:
While finishing the fight against
the pandemic must remain our central focus, we must continue building a strong
middle class and work toward a better future where everyone has a real and
fair chance at success and no one is left behind.

As Minister of Health, your immediate priority is to help finish the fight
against COVID-19, working in close cooperation with provinces and territories.
As we emerge from this pandemic, I expect you to work in partnership with
provinces and territories to strengthen our universal public health care
system and public health supports, backed by an early increase of investments
in primary and virtual care and mental health services so all Canadians can
get the care they need no matter where they live

The Public Health Agency of Canada will be provided with necessary resources.
Border management with the United States and other ports of entry will be handled responsibly.

summary.summary: The minister is responsible for actively engaging with cabinet and caucus colleagues to ensure collaborative and constructive support for rigorous and productive decision-making as the ministry delivers on its platform commitments.

chunk_text:
As Minister, you are also responsible for actively engaging with your cabinet
and caucus colleagues. As we deliver on our platform commitments, it will be
important that members of the ministry continue to collaborate and work
constructively to support rigorous and productive cabinet decision-making

summary.summary: You are expected to support colleagues in fulfilling their commitments by leveraging your department's expertise and personal experiences. For effective results, a rigorous and coordinated approach is necessary. Please provide a proposed approach for delivering your mandate commitments, highlighting early implementation priorities.

chunk_text:
I
expect you to support your colleagues in delivering their commitments,
leveraging the expertise of your department and your own lived experiences.

To best achieve results for Canadians, Ministers must be rigorous and
coordinated in our approach to implementation. I would therefore ask that you
return to me with a proposed approach for the delivery of your mandate
commitments, including priorities for early implementation

summary.summary: To ensure accountability, regular public reports on progress toward commitments will be required. The importance of adapting to change, as demonstrated during the pandemic, is emphasized as a critical role for government.

chunk_text:
Furthermore, to
ensure we are accountable for our work, I will be asking you to publicly
report to me, and all Canadians, on your progress toward these commitments on
a regular basis.

As we have been reminded throughout the pandemic, adapting to change is not
only something government should do, it is something government must do

summary.summary: You are expected to actively consider new ideas and issues as they emerge, through public engagement, work with Parliamentarians, and advice from the public service. Additionally, you should collaborate with your Deputy Minister to continually assess priorities to build a better future for all Canadians.

chunk_text:
As
you work to fulfil our commitments, I expect you to actively consider new
ideas and issues as they emerge, whether through public engagement, your work
with Parliamentarians or advice from the public service. I also expect you to
work with your Deputy Minister to assess priorities on a continual basis as we
build a better future for all Canadians

summary.summary: You are responsible for overseeing your department, ensuring its effective operation, and staffing your office. When implementing outreach and recruitment strategies for federally appointed leadership positions and boards, uphold the principles of equity, diversity, and inclusion to ensure federal workplaces reflect the population they serve.

chunk_text:
In addition to achieving results, you
are responsible for overseeing the work of your department and ensuring the
effective operation of your portfolio.

As you staff your office and implement outreach and recruitment strategies for
federally appointed leadership positions and boards, I ask that you uphold the
principles of equity, diversity and inclusion. This helps ensure that federal
workplaces are dynamic and reflective of the Canadians we serve

summary.summary: Ensure the Minister’s office and portfolio reflect a commitment to healthy and safe workplaces, and meet Canadians' expectations of hard work, truthfulness, and dedication to advancing their interests and aspirations.

chunk_text:
You will also
ensure your Minister’s office and portfolio are reflective of our commitment
to healthy and safe workplaces.

Canadians expect us to work hard, speak truthfully and be committed to
advancing their interests and aspirations

summary.summary: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau emphasizes the importance of acknowledging and learning from mistakes. He expresses confidence in the recipient's ability to fulfill their responsibilities and encourages them to seek support from him and the Deputy Prime Minister as needed.

chunk_text:
When we make mistakes – as we all
will – Canadians expect us to acknowledge them, and most importantly, to learn
from them.

I know I can count on you to fulfill the important responsibilities entrusted
in you, and to turn to me, and the Deputy Prime Minister, early and often to
support you in your role as Minister.

Sincerely,  
Rt. Hon. Justin Trudeau, P.C., M.P.  
Prime Minister of Canada

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.summary: On December 16, 2021, Minister Bennett was appointed as the Minister of Mental Health and Addictions and Associate Minister of Health. The letter acknowledges the significant challenges Canadians have faced during the pandemic and the resilience shown by people across the country.

chunk_text:
Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

December 16, 2021

Dear Minister Bennett:

Thank you for agreeing to serve Canadians as Minister of Mental Health and
Addictions and Associate Minister of Health.

From the beginning of this pandemic, Canadians have faced a once-in-a-century
challenge. And through it all, from coast to coast to coast, people have met
the moment
organizational_structure_keywords: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.summary: Canadians adapted and supported each other with compassion, courage, and determination during the pandemic. They made a democratic choice to entrust their government to continue fighting COVID-19 and support the recovery of a strong middle class.

chunk_text:
When it mattered most, Canadians adapted, helped one another, and
stayed true to our values of compassion, courage and determination. That is
what has defined our path through this pandemic so far. And that is what will
pave our way forward.

During a difficult time, Canadians made a democratic choice. They entrusted us
to finish the fight against COVID-19 and support the recovery of a strong
middle class

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.summary: The government has received a clear mandate to take bold and concrete actions to build a healthier and more resilient future, as requested by Canadians. The government is committed to delivering on this mandate through collaboration, engagement, and science and evidence-based decision-making.

chunk_text:
At the same time, they also gave us clear direction: to take
bold, concrete action to build a healthier, more resilient future. That is
what Canadians have asked us to do and it is exactly what our Government is
ready to deliver. We will work to build that brighter future through continued
collaboration, engagement, and the use of science and evidence-based decision-
making

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.summary: The government is committed to working constructively with Parliamentarians and maintaining strong partnerships with various levels of government and Indigenous partners to rebuild a more resilient, inclusive, and stronger country. Recognizing the clear scientific and public consensus, the government pledges to accelerate and intensify climate action.

chunk_text:
With an unwavering focus on delivering results, we will work
constructively with Parliamentarians and maintain our strong partnerships with
provincial, territorial and municipal governments and Indigenous partners.
This decade has had an incredibly difficult start, but this is the moment to
rebuild a more resilient, inclusive and stronger country for everyone.

The science is clear. Canadians have been clear. We must not only continue
taking real climate action, we must also move faster and go further

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.summary: Climate change poses a significant threat to Canadians, and addressing it will necessitate a sustained and collaborative effort from everyone to build a cleaner, greener future.

chunk_text:
As
Canadians are increasingly experiencing across the country, climate change is
an existential threat. Building a cleaner, greener future will require a
sustained and collaborative effort from all of us

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.text: As a Minister, you are expected to seek opportunities within your portfolio to support the government's efforts to reduce emissions, create clean jobs, and address climate-related challenges faced by communities.

This year, Canadians were shocked by the discovery of unmarked graves and burial sites near former residential schools, highlighting the urgent need to accelerate reconciliation efforts with First Nations, Inuit, and Métis Peoples.

chunk_text:
As Minister, I expect you
to seek opportunities within your portfolio to support our whole-of-government
effort to reduce emissions, create clean jobs and address the climate-related
challenges communities are already facing.

This year, Canadians were horrified by the discovery of unmarked graves and
burial sites near former residential schools. These discoveries underscore
that we must move faster on the path of reconciliation with First Nations,
Inuit and Métis Peoples

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.summary: The government acknowledges that reconciliation requires truth and commits to investing in uncovering that truth.

chunk_text:
We know that reconciliation cannot come without truth
and our Government will continue to invest in that truth

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.summary: Each Minister is directed to implement the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples and to work in partnership with Indigenous Peoples to advance their rights. The focus is on addressing systemic inequities and disparities present in society and its core institutions.

chunk_text:
As Ministers, each
of us has a duty to further this work, both collectively and as individuals.
Consequently, I am directing every Minister to implement the United Nations
Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples and to work in partnership
with Indigenous Peoples to advance their rights.

We must continue to address the profound systemic inequities and disparities
that remain present in the core fabric of our society, including our core
institutions

To this effect, it is essential that Canadians in every region
of the country see themselves reflected in our Government’s priorities and our
work. As Minister, I expect you to include and collaborate with various
communities, and actively seek out and incorporate in your work, the diverse
views of Canadians

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.summary: The text emphasizes the commitment to inclusive public policy development, ensuring that policies are informed and developed through an intersectional lens, particularly using frameworks like Gender-based Analysis Plus (GBA Plus) and quality of life indicators. It highlights the importance of considering diverse groups, including women, Indigenous Peoples, Black and racialized Canadians, newcomers, faith-based communities, persons with disabilities, and LGBTQ2 Canadians, in both official languages. It also notes the ongoing reliance on journalists and journalism for accurate and timely news.

This includes women, Indigenous Peoples, Black and
racialized Canadians, newcomers, faith-based communities, persons with
disabilities, LGBTQ2 Canadians, and, in both official languages.

Across our work, we remain committed to ensuring that public policies are
informed and developed through an intersectional lens, including applying
frameworks such as Gender-based Analysis Plus (GBA Plus) and the quality of
life indicators in decision-making.

Canadians continue to rely on journalists and journalism for accurate and
timely news

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.summary: The text emphasizes maintaining professional and respectful relationships with journalists to ensure Canadians are well-informed and safe. It also highlights the importance of learning from the pandemic to develop more agile and effective government services.

chunk_text:
I expect you to maintain professional and respectful
relationships with journalists to ensure that Canadians are well informed and
have the information they need to keep themselves and their families safe.

Throughout the course of the pandemic, Canadians and their governments have
adapted to new realities. Governments must draw on lessons learned from the
pandemic to further adapt and develop more agile and effective ways to serve
Canadians

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.summary: The text outlines expectations for Ministers to update government practices to meet current and future challenges. It emphasizes the need for Parliamentarians from all parties to collaborate effectively, maintain constructive relationships, and coordinate legislation to achieve significant outcomes for Canadians.

chunk_text:
To this end, I expect all Ministers to evaluate ways we can update
our practices to ensure our Government continues to meet the challenges of
today and tomorrow.

The success of this Parliament will require Parliamentarians, both in the
House of Commons and the Senate, to work together across all parties to get
big things done for Canadians. I expect you to maintain constructive
relationships with your Opposition Critics and coordinate any legislation with
the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons

summary.summary: The Minister is accountable to Parliament both individually for their leadership and performance, and collectively for the Ministry's and Cabinet's decisions. The document 'Open and Accountable Government' outlines the principles and standards of conduct expected of the Minister, which includes familiarizing oneself with the document to meet the expectations of the Ministry. The platform sets an ambitious agenda.

chunk_text:
As Minister, you are
accountable to Parliament both individually, for your style of leadership and
the performance of your responsibilities, and collectively, in support of our
Ministry and decisions taken by cabinet. Open and Accountable Government sets
out these core principles and the standards of conduct expected of you and
your office. I expect you to familiarize yourself with this document, which
outlines my expectations for each member of the Ministry.

Our platform lays out an ambitious agenda

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.summary: The priority remains to conclude the fight against the pandemic, while also focusing on building a strong middle class and ensuring equitable opportunities for success. As the Minister of Mental Health and Addictions and Associate Minister of Health, the role involves working with the Minister of Health to address health inequities, particularly for Indigenous Peoples, Black Canadians, and vulnerable Canadians, to build a healthier future.

chunk_text:
While finishing the fight against
the pandemic must remain our central focus, we must continue building a strong
middle class and work toward a better future where everyone has a real and
fair chance at success and no one is left behind.

As Minister of Mental Health and Addictions and Associate Minister of Health,
you will work with the Minister of Health to build a healthier future, with a
particular focus on ensuring that health inequities are understood and
addressed, including for Indigenous Peoples, Black Canadians and vulnerable
Canadians

Minister of Mental Health and Addictions

section_title: Minister of Mental Health and Addictions mandate letter

summary.summary: The task involves ensuring mental health care is integrated into Canada's universal health care system, collaborating with provinces, territories, and leading a comprehensive approach to substance use issues. Key commitments include working with the Minister of Health and other ministers to establish a permanent Canada Mental Health Transfer, aimed at expanding access to high-quality, free mental health services, including prevention and treatment.

chunk_text:
You will work to ensure that mental health care is treated as a
full and equal part of our universal health care system, working in close
collaboration with provinces and territories, and lead a whole-of-society
approach to address problematic substance use in Canada.

To realize these objectives, I ask that you achieve results for Canadians by
delivering the following commitments.

  * Work with the Minister of Health, and with the support of the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance, to establish a permanent, ongoing Canada Mental Health Transfer to help expand the delivery of high-quality, accessible and free mental health services, including for prevention and treatment
